I. Striated Muscle - regularly arranged contractile units A. Skeletal Muscle - long, cylindrical multinucleated cells with peripherally placed nuclei.
Contraction is typically quick and vigorous and under voluntary control.
Used for locomotion, mastication, and phonation.
B. Cardiac Muscle - elongated, branched cells with a single centrally placed nucleus and intercalated discs at the ends.
Contraction is involuntary, vigorous, and rhythmic.
Smooth Muscle - possesses contractile machinery, but it is irregularly arranged (thus, non-striated).
Cells are fusiform with a central nucleus.
Contraction is involuntary, slow, and long lasting.
Epiimysium - dense irr. c.t. Perimysium - less dense irr. c.t. Endomysium - basal lamina and reticular fibers
ALL MUSCLE CELLS HAVE BASAL LAMINAE!

T-tubule System: Propagation of the Signal and Release of $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$
[LIST_ITEM] conduct membrane depolarization deep into fibers
[LIST_ITEM] terminal cisternae abut T-tubules forming triads when myofibrils are viewed in longitudinal section
[H1] Longitudinal section of muscle showing triads.
[LIST_ITEM] Normally at A/I junctions in mammals (this sample is from an amphibian)
[LIST_ITEM] Action potential (AP) stimulates release of acetylcholine from axon terminal into synaptic cleft
[LIST_ITEM] Acetylcholine in synaptic cleft binds Na⁺ channel receptors –initiates sarcolemma AP
[LIST_ITEM] Conduct membrane depolarization deep into fibers
[LIST_ITEM] Smooth ER, site of Ca²⁺ storage
[LIST_ITEM] Voltage-gated channels in SR detect membrane depolarization in T-tubule and release Ca²⁺
[H1] $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$ Stimulates Myosin-Actin Binding and Initiates Contraction.
[LIST_ITEM] TnC binds Ca²⁺ (if present) and induces release of TnI from actin
[LIST_ITEM] Myosin binds actin; hydrolysis of ATP induces power stroke
[LIST_ITEM] Actin filaments move relative to myosin
Top left from Ross and Pawlina. Figure 11.7.
Bottom left and right. Figures 10-13 and 10-14 (right). Junquiera.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] ATP binds myosin – myosin releases actin
[NUMBERED_ITEM] ATP hydrolysis induces conformational change – myosin head cocks forward 5nm (ADP+Pᵢ remain bound to myosin).
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Myosin binds weakly to actin, causing release of Pᵢ
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Release of Pᵢ induces strong binding, power stroke, and release of ADP
Myosin remains bound to actin if no more ATP is available (rigor conformation)
Note: Z lines move closer together; I band and H band become smaller during contraction
[H2] Muscle fibers are composed of many contractile units (sarcomeres).
Changes in the amount of overlap between thick and thin filaments allows for contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
Many fibers contracting together result in gross movement
[LIST_ITEM] Rate of contractions modulated by autonomic nervous system
[LIST_ITEM] innervation is neuroendocrine in nature (i.e. no "motor end plates")
[LIST_ITEM] Numerous mitochondria (up to 40% of cell volume)
[LIST_ITEM] Sarcoplasmic reticulum & T-tubules appear as diads at Z lines
[LIST_ITEM] Sarcoplasmic reticulum does not form terminal cisternae
[LIST_ITEM] T tubules are about 2x larger in diameter than in skeletal muscle
Gartner and Hiatt. Color Atlas of Histology. Figure 2 and Figure 4 from Plate 6.8

[LIST_ITEM] Contraction is modulated in a neuroendocrine manner
[LIST_ITEM] Found in blood vessels, GI and urogenital organ walls, dermis of skin

[LIST_ITEM] intermediate filaments of desmin (also vimentin in vascular smooth muscle)
[LIST_ITEM] membrane associated and cytoplasmic dense bodies containing α actinin (similar to Z lines)
[LIST_ITEM] relatively active nucleus (smooth muscle cells make collagen, elastin, and proteoglycans)
May, Naftel, and Ard. University of Mississippi Digital EM Atlas. Plate 17A.

What is the structure marked by *?
Also, note collagen – SMC secrete ECM: collagen (I,III, IV), elastin, and proteoglycans
May, Naftel, and Ard. University of Mississippi Digital EM Atlas. Plate 17B
[H1] More Ultrastructure of Smooth Muscle Cells:.
[LIST_ITEM] caveoli (membrane invaginations & vesicular system contiguous with SER –functionally analogous to sarcoplasmic reticulum)
Cross and Mercer. Inset of plate 114.
also Ca+ dependent, but mechanism is different than striated muscle
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Ca2+ ions released from caveloae/SER and complex with calmodulin
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Ca2+-calmodulin activates myosin light chain kinase
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Myosin unfolds & binds actin; ATP-dependent contraction cycle ensues.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Contraction continues as long as myosin is phosphorylated.

[NUMBERED_ITEM] "Latch" state: myosin head attached to actin dephosphorylated causing decrease in ATPase activity – myosin head unable to detach from actin (similar to "rigor mortis" in skeletal muscle).
[LIST_ITEM] Voltage-gated Ca+ channels activated by depolarization
[LIST_ITEM] Dense bodies are analogous to Z lines (plaques into which actin filaments insert)
[LIST_ITEM] Myosin heads oriented in "side polar" arrangement
[LIST_ITEM] Contraction cycle generally about ~10% as fast as skeletal muscle

[LIST_ITEM] Visceral (unitary) smooth muscle cells may be electrically coupled via gap junctions and exhibit either rhythmic or tonic contraction – innervation generally MODIFIES smooth muscle activity rather than initiating it.
[LIST_ITEM] Multiunit smooth muscle cells are innervated individually and can contract rapidly for more precise control.
[LIST_ITEM] Innervation is always at a distance (no motor end plates)

[LIST_ITEM] Satellite cells are proposed source of regenerative cells
[LIST_ITEM] Smooth muscle cells are proliferative (e.g. uterine myometrium and vascular smooth muscle)
[LIST_ITEM] Vascular pericytes can also provide source of smooth muscle
[LIST_ITEM] New evidence suggests mitotic cardiomyocytes and regeneration by blood or vascular-derived stem cells
[H1] Activated satellite cell in skeletal muscle.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to identify the three types of muscle at the light and electron microscope levels, including distinctive features of each, such as the intercalated disk of cardiac muscle.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to describe the structural basis of muscle striation.

[NUMBERED_ITEM] Know the structural elements that harness muscle contraction (i.e., the shortening of myofibrils) to the movement of a body part (i.e., via connection to bone) as well as the mechanism by which muscle cells contract.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Understand the function and organization of the connective tissue in muscle (endo-, peri-, and epiysium).
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be familiar with the regenerative potential of each muscle type.
